abstract.para: &slereg; (&slea;) allows upgrading an existing system to the new version, for example, going from &slea; 12 SP4 to the latest &slea; &product-ga; service pack. No new installation is needed. Existing data, such as home and data directories and system configuration, is kept intact. You can update from a local CD or DVD drive or from a central network installation source.
&slemreg; allows upgrading from an existing system to the new version. No new installation is needed. Existing data, such as home and data directories and system configuration, is kept intact.

Upgrades between two releases of &productname; are supported by &suse;. Whether it is better to upgrade or perform a fresh installation depends on your specific scenario. While upgrades involve less work, fresh installations ensure you benefit from all the new features of a release such as disk layout changes, specific filesystem features, and other improvements. To get the most out of your system, &suse; therefore recommends fresh installations in most scenarios.
In both cases—upgrade as well as a fresh installation—customers need to check if system settings and default values still fit their requirements.
This chapter explains how to manually upgrade your &sle; system, be it by DVD, network, an automated process, or &susemgr;.

sect1.title: Upgrading versus fresh installation
sect1.para: Upgrades between two major releases of &productname; are supported by &suse;. Whether it is better to upgrade or perform a fresh installation depends on your specific scenario. While upgrades involve less work, fresh installations ensure you benefit from all the new features of a release such as disk layout changes, specific file system features, and other improvements. To get the most out of your system, &suse; therefore recommends fresh installations in most scenarios.
In both cases—upgrade as well as a fresh installation—customers need to check if system settings and default values still fit their requirements.

For updates from one service pack of a specific release to another one of the same codestream, &suse; recommends to do it in-place, and not to perform a fresh installation. Nevertheless there may be reasons and scenarios for a customer to perform a fresh installation in this case, too. The decision of which is more suitable can only be made by the customer.

sect1.title: Supported upgrade paths to &productnameshort; &productnumber;
sect1.para: Before you perform any migration, read .

important.title: Cross-architecture upgrades are not supported
important.para: Cross-architecture upgrades, such as upgrading from a 32-bit version of &productname; to the 64-bit version, or upgrading from big endian to little endian are not supported!
Specifically, &slea; 11 on &ppc; (big endian) to &slea; &productnumber; on &ppc; (new: little endian!) is not supported.
Also, since &sle; &product-ga; is 64-bit only, upgrades from any 32-bit &sle; 11 systems to &sle; &product-ga; and later are not supported.
To make a cross-architecture upgrade, you need to perform a new installation.

note.title: Skipping service packs
note.para: The easiest upgrade path is consecutively installing all service packs. For the &sle; &product-ga; product line (GA and the subsequent service packs) it is also supported to skip one service pack when upgrading. For example, upgrading from &slea; 15 GA to 15 SP2 or from &slea; 15 SP1 to 15 SP3 is supported.
Skipping service packs on &sled; is not supported. You need to consecutively install all service packs.

warning.title: Upgrading databases
warning.para: The upgrade paths described here apply only to &sle; as the operating system of a machine, not to all the applications it runs. If you have workloads such as &postgresql; or &mysql; databases, intermediate OS upgrades may be required in order to upgrade your databases.
Before upgrading the operating system, consult the Release Notes for information about database versions. If a new major version is shipped, refer to for upgrade instructions.

varlistentry.term: Upgrading from &productname; 11 GA / SP1 / SP2 / SP3 / SP4

listitem.para: Upgrading from &productnameshort; 11 SP4 or older service packs directly is not supported. You need at least &productnameshort; 11 SP4 LTSS before you can proceed to &productnameshort; &productnumber;.

If you cannot do a fresh installation, first upgrade your installed &productnameshort; 11 service pack to &productnameshort; 11 SP4 LTSS. This upgrade is described in the &productnameshort; 11 SP4 &deploy;.
Upgrading from &productnameshort; 11 SP4 is only supported via an offline upgrade. Refer to for details.

varlistentry.term: Upgrading from &productname; 12 GA / SP1 / SP2 / SP3 / SP4

listitem.para: Upgrading from &productnameshort; 12 SP4 or older service packs directly is not supported. You need at least &productnameshort; 12 SP5 before you can proceed to &productnameshort; &productnumber;.

If you cannot do a fresh installation, first upgrade your installed &productnameshort; 12 service pack to &productnameshort; 12 SP5. This upgrade is described in the &productnameshort; 12 SP5 &deploy;&productnameshort; 12 SP5 &deploy;.

varlistentry.term: Upgrading from &productname; 12 SP3 LTSS / SP4 LTSS

listitem.para: Upgrading from &productnameshort; 12 SP3 or SP4 with LTSS is only supported via an offline upgrade. Refer to for details.
Upgrading from &productnameshort; 12 SP5 is only supported via an offline upgrade. Refer to for details.
Upgrading from &productnameshort; 15 GA directly is not supported. You need at least &productnameshort; 15 SP1 before you can proceed to &productnameshort; &productnumber;.
Upgrading from &productnameshort; 15 GA or SP1 directly is not supported. You need at least &productnameshort; 15 SP2 before you can proceed to &productnameshort; &productnumber;.

Upgrading from &productnameshort; 15 SP1 or SP2 is supported both online and offline.
Refer to for details.

Upgrading from &productnameshort; 15 SP2 is supported both online and offline.
Refer to for details.
For instructions on upgrading &slea; guests in public clouds, see Using the SUSE Distribution Migration System.
Upgrading from &opensuse; Leap 15 is supported. See . Only the server installation of Leap is supported for an upgrade.

sect1.title: Online and offline upgrade
sect1.para: &suse; supports the following upgrade and migration methods. For more information about the terminology, see . The methods are:

listitem.para: Upgrades that are executed from the running operating system itself (system up and running state). Examples: online update with Zypper or &yast;, connected through &scc; or &rmtool; (&rmt;), Salt Policy via &susemgr;.
When migrating between Service Packs of the same major release, we suggest following or .

Upgrading offline implies that the operating system to be upgraded is not running (system down state). Instead, the installer for the target operating system is booted (for example, from the installation media, via network or via local boot loader), and performs the upgrade.
